awd_titl_txt: Writing Data Stories: Integrating Computational Data Investigations into the Middle School Science Classroom
awd_abstract_narration:
As a result of the powerful innovation and application of computing in STEM disciplines, the STEM+C program addresses an urgent need for real-world, interdisciplinary, and computational preparation of students from the early grades through high school (preK-12).  Preparing today's students to work with data fluently is critical to ensuring a scientifically literate and empowered citizenry. But most efforts to incorporate data analysis into the K-12 curriculum are limited to short, isolated activities; basic skills development; or, are introduced as new courses devoted specifically to data and computing, limiting both the potential benefits and the audience for such efforts. This project seeks to integrate computational data analysis into the middle school science curriculum in a longitudinal, interdisciplinary way - drawing from the computer and data sciences, literacy studies, statistics, and science education to saturate the classroom with relevant tools, resources, and support. Middle school classrooms will analyze and draw conclusions about publicly available scientific datasets using a free, innovative, computational data analysis platform called the Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP). Units will be designed specifically with Dual Language Learners (DLL) in mind, inviting students to share their investigations by writing multimodal texts that blend both familiar and academic modes of expression to explain and contextualize their data analysis processes. Units that build on one another in difficulty and complexity will be introduced throughout the academic year, and participating teachers will receive significant training opportunities. Overall the project is anticipated to directly impact approximately 2,500 students and 20 teachers in the greater San Francisco Bay area, from predominantly high needs schools.

The project will provide a research context to address the following questions: How do students learn, over time, to use computational tools to structure, calculate, filter, and transform data for scientific inquiry? What patterns of engagement in scientific practices are supported by the integration of computational data analysis and visualizations into the science curriculum? And, what new literacy practices might support DLL and learners with limited access to technology or who are still developing academic literacy in constructing oral and written arguments and explanations using data and visualizations as evidence? Specifically, it brings together and seeks to extend three complementary research constructs. Data moves are the computational actions analysts take to transform and analyze datasets. Syncretic texts are specialized texts that blend academic discourse, such as the formulae and statistical language needed to explain data analysis, with the familiar modes of expression (including home languages and alternative forms of expression such as video, art, animation, etc.), which has been found to invite a wide range of marginalized students to experiment with and develop academic language. Finally, a community of learners approach allows different student groups in a classroom to conduct and share the results of different investigations with the same dataset, making the exploration of large and complex data more feasible in everyday classrooms. Analyses will make use of video, CODAP log data, students' written texts, and pre-post assessments to investigate learning and participation longitudinally over the course of an entire academic year.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

The goal of the Writing Data Stories project is to help classroom communities build a toolkit of skills, materials, and literacy strategies for conducting investigations, engaging in arguments, and developing solutions to important problems using public datasets. The main premise is that working with data must be understood as the construction of scientific texts, and that "data stories" can help students describe connections between dataset, analysis, and context. In our conceptualization, "data stories" are a narrative that integrates a personal rationale for data analysis, an accounting of steps taken in data analysis, and an analysis of the implications of results for the system being investigated.

To do this well requires pedagogical, technical, and curricular support. Public datasets and data visualizations can allow students to explore some of the most important scientific issues of our time. But they are also large, messy, and more complex than typical educational datasets. This poses technical and conceptual issues for educators, curriculum designers, and learners. The Writing Data Stories project sought to address these challenges and explored the pedagogical potential of data storytelling through producing:

  1. Publicly-available, bilingual curricular materials and frameworks for supporting data storytelling in classroom contexts.

  2. Research examining the enactment of data storytelling in middle school classrooms and in teacher professional development settings.

  3. Two new plugins for the popular Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP) and associated enhancements that support data storytelling.

  4. Outreach and professional development through teacher workshops, case studies, and materials shared with national and international audiences.

Curricular Materials and Frameworks

As of the end of this project, the WDS project has fully developed three full curricular units; a widely applicable DataBytes data visualization discussion protocol and associated guides for ten activities; and a collection of five Data Launchpads that scaffold students' introductions to large, public datasets from the Environmental Protection Agency, Pew Research, CalEnviroScreen, and other major public organizations. 

Our original plan to develop several multi-week curriculum units was disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. However, we instead produced a more flexible range of materials. Our DataBytes protocol in particular has been widely taken up beyond the project and integrated into a variety of other activities and major professional development efforts.

Research on Teacher and Student Learning

We took a design research approach to conduct research using these materials, and to further refine these materials in response to our findings. Our contributions include peer-reviewed articles that: 

  • Explore humanistic and literacy-based approaches to data science education that acknowledge both strengths and limitations in how data are collected, analyzed, and interpreted.
  • Report the different goals and orientations that teachers may take toward integrating "data talks" or "data discussions" in their own classrooms, and these teachers’ perceived support needs.
  • Offer working definitions of "data storytelling," a still ill-defined concept in the field, that accommodate a wide diversity of student products and can map to different intended learning outcomes.

Plugins for Working with Public Datasets in CODAP

As part of our project's work to reduce the technical barriers to exploring larger, publicly-shared datasets in classrooms, we developed a variety of new features within CODAP. 

Choosy is a plugin for the CODAP tool that allows designers to easily hide, group, and reveal collections of attributes in large datasets. For example, an educator who would like students to explore a pollution dataset may first reveal only one pollutant while leading a shared investigation. They can then invite students to select their own pollutant to reveal and investigate, or to identify a class of pollutants that can be revealed together for a deeper multivariate investigation (e.g. water pollutants, air pollutants, heavy metals, etc.).

Story Builder is a plugin that allows users to record and narrate key moments of their analysis within CODAP. These can then be played back by others in an interactive way; for example users may revisit earlier moments of an analysis and pursue a new branch of investigation with the same dataset. This is meant to provide students with an accounting of their data moves (a preliminary form of reproducibility), as well as to support connections between data and context. We also enhanced multimodal support for CODAP to embed video, pictures, websites, and rich text to support data stories.

Outreach and Community Building

Over five years, this project directly impacted over fifty educators in a sustained (e.g. multi-year, multi-week, or multi-engagement) way, and hundreds through shorter-term one time workshops, presentations, and resource distribution. Our project has been featured in a variety of high-profile meetings concerning Data Science Education including a 2022 National Academies Workshop, ongoing activities of the Data Science for Everyone and American Statistical Associations, and at a 2024 survey of Data Science Education research projects presented at the International Congress of Mathematical Education.
